ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Different perspectives/theories of criminal wrongdoing, and how these could be applied to crimes enabled by emerging technologies.

theory of criminal law (deterrence, retributivism, positivism, expressivism), why do we make certain crimes criminal, why do we punish and how should we punish. Then, we apply a lot of these frameworks to new crimes such as deep fakes and cyber crimes
A solid understanding of the utilitarian, retributive, and expressive theories of crime & punishment, as well as the ability to apply these theories to novel digitally-aided forms of wrongdoing.

I learned so much about the types of future crimes and technologies that we're going to be facing in the coming years and how we can start to think about regulating them, or even if we should at all. It was a class that definitely left me with more questions than answers.
Various theories and approaches to discussing criminality and approaching punishment; applications of these theoretical frameworks to novel forms of criminality made possible by emerging technologies

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The interesting readings and class discussions were strengths; a suggestion would be to expand the second half of the course to cover more types of applications of crime and emerging tech.

Professor Maggen is truly amazing. He's kind, thoughtful, intelligent, and patient. Everyone's course background was highly varied which made for a lot of intriguing perspectives on criminal law theory and its applications
super manageable workload; every assignment felt purposeful and useful. i learnt so much, and covered material I'd likely not encounter in other Yale classes.

Our pre-class virtual discussions on Canvas were really interesting to read and made me feel more connected to my classmates. However, I sometimes felt that people (me included) tended to summarize their posts/responses to drive class discussion, which created a slight sense of redundancy. I think class worked best when Professor Maggen briefly summarized the main threads of our discussion and asked related questions that we hadn't thought of or answered.
The discussion board was really useful! I did think that the thing he did in the beginning of the class where he gave a brief presentation overviewing the topics would have been helpful to continue.
Super interesting topics, open-ended / flexible essay topics, well-organized, and a fabulous professor who really cares!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, super interesting topics and you don't have to have much background to take this course.

Definitely! Danny truly cares about each and every student and was happy to meet with me on several occasions to go over my ideas for my paper. He's extremely intelligent and knowledgeable about all the topics we discussed in a down to earth manner where you feel comfortable talking to him.
Amazing course!! Take it if you have the chance. Most wonderful Professor and incredibly engaging class.

absolutely! the class discussions were fascinating, the readings were great, and prof. maggen is a wonderful teacher. this seminar had perhaps the highest rate of student engagement of any class i've taken at yale -- a feat given the Zoom format -- with pretty much everyone engaging in discussion each week & contributing unique perspectives.

Yes, I would. It gives you a really helpful foundation in theories of crime and punishment and in the relationship between legal and social realms, which you can then apply to the incredibly interesting issues that will occupy our legal systems for decades to come: deep fakes, AI culpability, platform liability, virtual crimes.....this class really does pique your interests and imagination. I'd recommend it. Professor Maggen is also very available to help sharpen your ideas and discuss issues with you outside of class.
Yes definitely - Professor Maggen is awesome and the readings/topics are fascinating!!
Yes! He is a great professor who is very passionate about the material.
Definitely!

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the issues of legal theory and what constitutes a crime. The discussions in class and online were also extremely thought-provoking and stimulating, and were an enriching part of the class.
